awd_titl_txt: RUI: The transcriptional response to quantitative variation in RpoS concentration in E. coli
awd_abstract_narration:
This project develops a quantitative understanding of how bacteria turn their genes on and off in response to stresses. This project will provide undergraduate students with experience performing research in microbiology, molecular genetics, and genomics. In addition, the PI will provide research internships to high school students participating in an Upward Bound program. These students are from backgrounds underrepresented in science, and the internships will give these students a path towards careers in science.
	
The project studies two major questions about how the transcription of genes in the E. coli genome varies in response to the concentration of the regulatory protein RpoS. First, the project will test the role of specific transcription factors (TFs) in altering how genes respond to RpoS levels. This will be done by RNA-seq studies of the response to RpoS levels in strains lacking certain TFs. These whole genome studies will be complemented by detailed manipulations of TF binding sites in specific promoters. Second, the research will characterize the dose-response relationship between RpoS and transcription, and its influence over a physiological transition. This research will be done by altering RpoS levels using an arabinose-inducible RpoS system, and then measuring the effect on transcription using RNA-seq.

por.por_cntn:
Biologists have known for about 60 years that the activity of proteins inside of cells regulates the expression of genes. The number and kinds of regulatory proteins identified in model organisms continues to expand. In spite of this knowledge, biologists generally lack is a quantitative understanding of these regulatory interactions. For example, how does the amount of a regulatory protein determine the nature and extent of regulatory interactions?

This project examined how variation in the abundance of the regulatory protein RpoS, found in the model bacterium Escherichia coli, influences the transcription of all genes in the genome. RpoS helps E. coli respond to many different stresses, but the importance of the fact that different stresses upregulate RpoS to different levels has been obscure. Prior to this project, the investigators found that: 1) the shape of the relationship between RpoS levels and level of transcription varies dramatically between different RpoS-regulated genes; 2) that these differing responses to RpoS levels likely have important physiological consequences and may coordinate the timing of gene expression; and, 3) that the response is likely controlled by the binding of transcription factors to the regulatory regions of these RpoS-regulated genes.

In this project, the investigators characterized the expression of every gene in the genome in response to three stresses: stationary phase, low temperature, and elevated osmolarity. The found that while RpoS regulates genes across all of these stresses, the timing of the RpoS-dependent response differs strongly between the three stresses, and that the response in each stress is uncorrelated with responses to the other stresses. These findings are consistent with previous findings that the response is likely controlled by the binding of transcription factors.

Undergraduate student research and training was a central part of the success of this project. Student researchers included those enrolled Harvey Mudd College as well as those who are graduates from HMC's Upward Bound program, which works with first-generation and underrepresented minority students from local high schools to help them succeed in college.
